document_data.caption: "Jotun", written in [[Dethek]] runes.
document_data.name: Jotun
document_data.mainbody:
lieved by some to be derived from the [[Primordial language]], the Giant tongue was taught to the giants by [[Annam All-Father]]. Not long after giant culture first began to flourish, the Dwarvish script Dethek was adopted for transcribing Giantish.

Jotunstein had strong [[Dwarvish|Auld Dwarven]] influences. And both Thorass and, to an extent the, Common tongue of Faerûn were thought to share lingual roots with Jotun, possibly having evolved from an even more ancient giant language.<ref>

Only about 1% of giants had any significant knowledge of the ancient giant runes in [[1366 DR]].{{Giantcraft date}}<ref> By the late 14th century DR, a few giants were familiar with the rune commonly associated with their subrace and the runes were still used by giant runecasters.<ref> Most ancient dragons were also familiar with the large majority of these runes.
document_data.Script: Both ancient and modern Giant was written with [[Dethek]] runes. although they were also used symbolically in art to represent or refer to related giant subraces and gods. These runes did not make up a true alphabet or syllabary, but rather they were diagrams or models of the relationships between cosmic forces and the deeper truths of the universe.

Grammar.Nouns: The plural forms of nouns varied depending on the declension. For example, the plural of ''jotun'' ("giant") was ''jotunen'', while the plural of ''huslyd'' ("family") was ''huslyder''.

The two demonstrative pronouns were ''i'' and ''det'', "this" and "that", respectively. The interrogative pronouns included ''wo'' ("what"), ''wer'' ("who"), and ''wie'' ("where").
Grammar.Numbers:
The cardinal numbers in Jotun are listed below:
{|

| ''et''
|-
| 2

|-

|-

| ''fir''
|-
| 5
| ''fem''
|-
| 6
| ''sek''
|-
| 7
| ''sju''
|-
| 8
| ''att''
|-
| 9
| ''ni''
|-
| 10
| ''tier''
|-
| 100
| ''hund''
|-
| 1,000
| ''tusen''
|-
|}

Numbers after ten were formed simply by following ten with the next digit, as in ''tier et'', that is, there was no separate word for eleven. 20 and 30 were represented with ''to tier'' and ''tre tier''. Similarly, 2,345 would be represented as ''to tusen tre hund fir tier fem''.

The only ordinal number known to scholars was ''stot'', "second".

Derivatives.Jogishk: This is the patois spoken by [[ogre]]s.{{Cite dragon annual/1999/Speaking in Tongues|29}}
Derivatives.Jotunalder: Similar enough to Jotun to be reasonably understood, this language has not changed in thousands of years and is used formally in ceremonies.
Derivatives.Hill giant language|Jotunhaug: Spoken by [[hill giant|hill]] and [[mountain giant]]s, and closely related to Jotunise.
Derivatives.Jotunise: Spoken by [[frost giant]]s and closely related to Jotunhaug.
Derivatives.Jotunskye: The language used by [[cloud giant|cloud]] and [[fog giant]]s.
Derivatives.Kara-Turan hill giant: A dialect spoken exclusively by the hill giants of [[Kara-Tur]], such as the [[coombe giant]]s.<ref>
